section.title: Glossaries
section.para: Glossaries are terminology files that are stored in the folder.
All terms in a segment with a match in any of the glossaries will be displayed in the pane.
Source terms can be multi-word expressions.

There are 2 kinds of glossary files:
The project glossary
You can use to enter new terms in this glossary. It is called the writable glossary for this reason.
You can also access it with , open it in a text editor and modify it.
You do not need to prepare the file in advance.
It will be created the first time you add an entry to the glossary.
If you choose to use an existing file as the default glossary, check its format beforehand. OmegaT will record all new entries in tab-separated format, and save the file in UTF-8 encoding without checking the original format or character set.
The reference glossaries
They are terminology files in a format that OmegaT recognises. You cannot modify them from the OmegaT interface like the project glossary, but you can access them and modify them in a text editor.

note.para: As soon as you save the modifications you have made to any glossary, they will be taken into account by OmegaT and term matches will be automatically displayed in the pane.

section.title: The glossaries folder
section.para: By default, each project contains a folder to store the writable glossary and any reference glossaries you want to add to the project. See for details.
All glossaries must be located in the folder. Glossaries located in nested folders are also recognized.
You can create multiple terminology folders based on subject or client and point at them as your project requires by using the dialog.

section.title: Project glossary
section.para: The project writable glossary is by default located in the folder and called .
You can change its name and location in the dialog, but you must give it a .txt or .utf8 extension, and store it within the folder or in one of its subfolders.

section.title: File format
section.para: OmegaT glossary files are simple plain text files containing three-column lists, with the source term in the first column, an optional target term in the second column, and an optional comment in the third column.
Glossaries can be “tab-separated values” (TSV) or “comma-separated values” (CSV) files or can also use the TermBase eXchange (TBX) format.
The writable glossary for the project is always a TSV file saved in UTF-8 encoding.
